Getting Started

WK CSS is a self service, à la carte, CSS framework. It is open and freely available to all projects within Wolters Kluwer. Developers and designers can take only the parts of the framework needed for a project. It also provides a Bootstrap compatibility layer.

What’s Happening

Brand guidelines have recently changed and we’re aligning our components to adhere to them – so you don’t have to worry about it!

The next few version 0.x feature releases will likely have markup changes.

We’re ironing out the wrinkles on the way to version 1.0.

Assets via CDN

These pre-compiled CSS choices are for those who wish to use the library with minimal setup. If you want the leanest CSS, then you probably want to build your own with SCSS.

Standard Build

This build includes the following original components:

  • Alerts
  • Animation
  • Badges
  • Brand
  • Breadcrumbs
  • Buttons
  • Content Filter
  • Document
  • Footer
  • Header
  • Icons
  • Input
  • Labels
  • Layout
  • Modal
  • Navbar
  • Pagination
  • Popover
  • Product Name
  • Search
  • Tables
  • Toolbelt
  • Tooltip
  • Typography
If you are starting a new project and have not already started with Bootstrap, we recommend the standard build.

Use the standard version right from the CDN by putting this in your document <head>.

<link href="https://cdn.wolterskluwer.io/wk-css/0.16.x/standard.min.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet"/>

This version includes the collection of original Wolters Kluwer components plus these Bootstrap components:

  • badges

If you want the uncompressed CSS, drop the .min in the CDN path. 
<link href="https://cdn.wolterskluwer.io/wk-css/0.16.x/with-bootstrap.min.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet"/>

Customize (Build Your Own)

Prerequisites

  • Sass 3.4.2
  • libsass (not ruby sass)

The library uses sass maps and requires include paths to be specified.

We recommend gulp and gulp-sass for your build process.

Installation

NPM

WK CSS is published and made available as an NPM package. This is facilitated through the Private NPM Repository, a package registry which is completely free to use by any Wolters Kluwer developer. An NA account is required for instant access though additional support is underway to support multiple Wolters Kluwer account types. If you do not have an NA account but would like access, please contact either Ron Edgecomb or Evgeniy Podolyak for further instructions.

In order to bring WK CSS into your project as an NPM package you must first configure NPM to search the Private NPM Repository. This is a simple step which requires the creation of a .npmrc file in the root of your project. For more information on configuring NPM, please visit their official documentation.

If you plan on using the Private NPM Repository for multiple projects, please consider saving your .npmrc file in a parent or root directory which contains all of your projects. This single configuration will be used by any projects located within the directory and will prevent copying this file into multiple directories.

The Private NPM Repository search configuration includes an access token unique to your NA account. Please do not commit .npmrc to your project‘s code repository or share it with other developers on your team. Each developer must create their own .npmrc file containing their token.

Login to npm.wolterskluwer.io with your NA credentials. Once logged in, copy the contents of the generated .npmrc file into your project root or desired location. Below you will find a sample configuration. 

registry=https://npm.wolterskluwer.io/registry/UNIQUE_TOKEN

If not already present, please add a package.json file to the project with dependencies. You can use the npm init command to create this file interactively.

package.json example: 

{
  "name": "example",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "dependencies": {
    "angular": "*",
    "wk-css": "~0.16"
  }
}

Execute npm install to fetch dependencies

npm install

You may also install WK CSS directly from the NPM CLI

npm install wk-css --save

Bower

Windows users seeing the Filename too long error when installing with bower should run the following git command: git config core.longpaths true

To be compatible with a contemporary front end development workflow, WK CSS is published and made available as a Bower package. This is facilitated through the Private Bower Repository, a package registry which is completely free to use by any Wolters Kluwer developer. An NA account is required for instant access though additional support is underway to support multiple Wolters Kluwer account types. If you do not have an NA account but would like access, please contact either Ron Edgecomb or Evgeniy Podolyak for further instructions.

In order to bring WK CSS into your project as a Bower package you must first configure Bower to search the Private Bower Repository. This is a simple step which requires the creation of a .bowerrc file in the root of your project. For more information on configuring Bower, please visit their official documentation.

If you plan on using the Private Bower Repository for multiple projects, please consider saving your .bowerrc file in a parent or root directory which contains all of your projects. This single configuration will be used by any projects located within the directory and will prevent copying this file into multiple directories.

The Private Bower Repository search configuration includes an access token unique to your NA account. Please do not commit .bowerrc to your project‘s code repository or share it with other developers on your team. Each developer must create their own .bowerrc file containing their token.

Login to bower.wolterskluwer.io with your NA credentials. Once logged in, copy the contents of the generated .bowerrc file into your project root or desired location. Below you will find a sample configuration. 

{
  "registry": {
     "search": [
       "https://bower.wolterskluwer.io/registry/UNIQUE_ACCESS_TOKEN",
       "https://bower.herokuapp.com"
     ]
  }
}

If not already present, please add a bower.json file to the project with dependencies. You can use the bower init command to create this file interactively.

bower.json example: 

{
  "name": "example",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "dependencies": {
    "angular": "*",
    "wk-css": "~0.16"
  }
}

Execute bower install to fetch dependencies

bower install

You may also install WK CSS directly from the Bower CLI

bower install wk-css --save

Bamboo

Bamboo is a product development framework used within the GPO. The Bamboo package manager offers support of Bower packages allowing WK CSS to be configured within the Bamboo package descriptor file.

Add the following to your projects bamboo package descriptor file.

{
  "dependencies": {
      "bower:wk-css": "0.16.*"
  }
}

Then install the dependencies via the command line.

bmb install

Gulp Setup

You must not use a version of node-sass greater than 3.4.2 when building your own SCSS with WK CSS.

Use an exact version of node-sass in your project by omitting the leading ~ or ^ from the version number in your package.json. 

"devDependencies": {
    "node-sass": "3.4.2"
}

See an example project that uses WK CSS, including the relevant gulp tasks and node-sass fix.

Assuming you are using bower_components/, change the include paths to your gulp-sass task. WK CSS’s bower requirements will install the dependencies.

Autoprefixer is required for CSS vendor support (e.g automatically add -webkit-apperance: none; for appearance: none; rules).

We highly recommend csso for minification optimization.

gulp.src(paths.scss)
    .pipe(sass({
        includePaths: [
            // NOTE: if you’re upgrading from a version before 0.16, you must change the path to wk-css from 0.16 onward
            //   old: './bower_components/wk.css/src',
            //   new: './bower_components/wk-css/src',
            './bower_components/wk-css/src',
            './bower_components/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/',
            './bower_components/modular-scale/stylesheets',
            './bower_components/breakpoint-sass/stylesheets/',
            './bower_components/susy/sass/'
        ]
    }))
    .pipe(autoprefixer()) //necessary for a uniform cross browser experience
    .pipe(csso()) //minify the CSS

You may need an additional gulp task to copy the provided font assets to a fonts/ directory beneath the ultimate CSS directory. 

// add a task to copy the fonts to their final resting place (assuming bower_components/ and app/css/)
gulp.task('copy:wkFonts', function () {
    // NOTE: if you’re upgrading from a version before 0.16, you must change the path to wk-css from 0.16 onward
    //   old: gulp.src(['./bower_components/wk.css/src/wk-components/fonts/**/*'])
    //   new: gulp.src(['./bower_components/wk-css/src/wk-components/fonts/**/*'])
    gulp.src(['./bower_components/wk-css/src/wk-components/fonts/**/*'])
        .pipe(gulp.dest('app/css/fonts'));
});

You may need an additional gulp task to copy the provided image assets to an assets/.

// add a task to copy image assets to their final place
// assuming the './bower_components/wk-css/src/assets' is a source path and 'app/assets' is a destination path
// optionally (in case of images minification) should be installed and required the modules:

var imagemin = require('gulp-imagemin');
var pngquant = require('imagemin-pngquant');

gulp.task('copy:wkAssets', function () {
  // NOTE: if you’re upgrading from a version before 0.16, you must change the path to wk-css from 0.16 onward
  //   old: gulp.src(['./bower_components/wk.css/src/assets/**/*'])
  //   new: gulp.src(['./bower_components/wk-css/src/assets/**/*'])
  gulp.src(['./bower_components/wk-css/src/assets/**/*'])
      // apply minification for filtered subset of images (optional)
      .pipe(imagemin({
          progressive: true,
          svgoPlugins: [{removeViewBox: false}],
          use: [pngquant()]
      }))
      // copy image assets to the destination
      .pipe(gulp.dest('app/assets'));
});

Import SCSS

You should have one master document which coordinates all scss files to output a singular CSS file.

wk-init will load all the helper functions, mixins, and 3rd party libraries. 

// this your master.scss file which pulls it all together!
// wk-init comes first which includes prerequisites and libraries
@import 'wk-init';

Next, you might have your own scss variables or mixins. Include those partials.

Hold off on including anything that generates CSS output before wk-reset, wk-bootstrap-init, or wk-components-init.

Define which features to include from Bootstrap and WK CSS. The Bootstrap feature names correspond to those found in their documentation.

// WK CSS components
// e.g. choose specific components
$wk-component-features: (
  type
  brand
  layout
);

// or include everything from WK CSS
$wk-component-features: (all);

// Bootstrap features are included as desired
// e.g. specific components
$wk-bootstrap-features: (
  forms
  buttons
  navbar
);

// or include everything from Bootstrap
$wk-bootstrap-features: (all);

Include the provided CSS reset called wk-reset. It does a little more than Normalize, so we recommend using it.

// actual CSS output should begin with the reset
@import 'wk-reset';

Then you may include the actual feature components with wk-bootstrap-init and wk-components-init. 

// next, generate the CSS output for the elected features
@import 'wk-bootstrap-init';
@import 'wk-components-init';

Finally, include scss for specific pages and components

// everything else relating to this project essentially comes last
@import 'app/common/header/scss/header';
@import 'app/pages/document/scss/document';

Supported Browsers

We target evergreen browsers but are making special considerations for IE 9.

Start your HTML document with comments like these to get the most from our components:

<!DOCTYPE html><!--[if lt IE 9]><html class="ie"><![endif]--><!--[if IE 9]><html class="ie ie9"><![endif]--><!--[if (gt IE 9)|!(IE)]><!--><html><!--<![endif]-->

You will also need to include Modernizr.

<head>
  <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/modernizr/2.8.3/modernizr.min.js"></script>
</head>

▲ Back to top

Quality Guarantee

“We promise to follow these tenets of quality.” WK CSS Authors

1. Mobile First

Our original base styles are built mobile first.

2. Namespaced CSS and SCSS

Every original class we provide will start with .wk as a prefix. Similarly, every new scss function, mixin, or variable we provide ourselves will start with wk. We don’t want to step on your toes after all.

3. No-Hassle Font Sizing

We have curated the proper sizes for the provided official Wolters Kluwer fonts. You don’t have to worry about the pixel sizing, em sizing, or proportions. Just use the base elements like h1 or use our classes.

4. Consistent Margins

We favor bottom and right margins to separate visual elements as opposed to top and left. The pieces fit together in a reliable manner which means you can customize our styles and mixins easily.

5. Variable and Mixin Exposure

Anything that seems useful for consumer projects we expose via SCSS variables or refactor our implementation to utilize a SCSS mixin - so that you can use these things as you please.

6. Component Dependency Documentation

If your are implementing WK CSS with the source SCSS and you include an original component of ours, you may see a warning in the SCSS compilation process regarding dependencies. This is a feature not a bug! We document which components are dependent upon others for clarity’s sake.

▲ Back to top

SCSS Documentation

Built to be super configurable, WK CSS exposes many underlying variables and mixins so that you can build pages to suit the needs of your product. See the documentation here.
